articles.headline: Cablevision Is Winner of Newsday
articles.snippet: The owners of The New York Post and The Daily News lost out to Cablevision in the battle for Newsday on Monday, but the tabloid war may be far from over.
articles.abstract: The owners of The New York Post and The Daily News lost out to Cablevision in the battle for Newsday on Monday, but the tabloid war may be far from over.
articles.lead_paragraph: The owners of The New York Post and The Daily News lost out to Cablevision in the battle for Newsday on Monday, but the tabloid war may be far from over. Either paper could still strike a deal to share operations with Newsday, according to bankers and analysts.

articles.headline: Bloomberg L.P. Fills Post, Suggesting Shift to News
articles.snippet: Norman Pearlstine, the former top editor of Time Inc. and The Wall Street Journal, was named to the new position of chief content officer of Bloomberg on Monday.
articles.abstract: Norman Pearlstine, the former top editor of Time Inc. and The Wall Street Journal, was named to the new position of chief content officer of Bloomberg on Monday.
articles.lead_paragraph: The news business may be in the doldrums, but the competition over business news could be heating up.

articles.headline: Greenhouse Gas Must Be Capped, McCain Asserts
articles.snippet: Senator John McCain called for a limit on greenhouse gas emissions in the U.S.
articles.abstract: Senator John McCain called for a limit on greenhouse gas emissions in the U.S.
articles.lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore.  Senator John McCain sought to distance himself from President Bush on Monday as he called for a mandatory limit on greenhouse gas emissions in the United States to combat climate change.
articles.byline: By Elisabeth Bumiller and John M. Broder

articles.headline: Cigarette Bill Treats Menthol With Leniency
articles.snippet: A ban of most flavored cigarettes would exempt menthol cigarettes, popular among African-Americans.
articles.abstract: A ban of most flavored cigarettes would exempt menthol cigarettes, popular among African-Americans.
articles.lead_paragraph: Some public health experts are questioning why menthol, the most widely used cigarette flavoring and the most popular cigarette choice of African-American smokers, is receiving special protection as Congress tries to regulate tobacco for the first time.

articles.headline: Love on Girls’ Side of the Saudi Divide
articles.snippet: The separation between the sexes in Saudi Arabia is so extreme that it is difficult to overstate.
articles.abstract: The separation between the sexes in Saudi Arabia is so extreme that it is difficult to overstate.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia  The dance party in Atheer Jassem al-Othman’s living room was in full swing. The guests  about two dozen girls in their late teens  had arrived, and Ms. Othman and her mother were passing around cups of sweet tea and dishes of dates.

articles.headline: Hewlett-Packard Said to Be Close to Buying E.D.S.
articles.snippet: The deal, for $12 billion to $13 billion, would be Hewlett-Packard’s largest since its merger with Compaq.
articles.abstract: The deal, for $12 billion to $13 billion, would be Hewlett-Packard’s largest since its merger with Compaq.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  The Hewlett-Packard Company, the personal computer and printer maker, is close to a deal to acquire the Electronic Data Systems Corporation, the operator of corporate computer systems, for $12.6 billion in cash, people involved in the transaction said Monday.
articles.byline: By Matt Richtel and Andrew Ross Sorkin

articles.headline: ‘No Hope’ for Children Buried in Earthquake
articles.snippet: As dawn crept across the shattered town of Dujiangyan, the site of a school collapse became a center of mourning.
articles.abstract: As dawn crept across the shattered town of Dujiangyan, the site of a school collapse became a center of mourning.
articles.lead_paragraph: DUJIANGYAN, China  The children who were considered fortunate escaped with a broken bone or a severed limb. The others, hundreds of them, were carried out to be buried, and their remaining classmates lay crushed beneath the rubble of the schoolhouse.

articles.headline: Nissan Plans Electric Car in U.S. by ’10
articles.snippet: The commitment, announced Tuesday, will be the first by a major automaker to bring a zero-emission vehicle to the American market.
articles.abstract: The commitment, announced Tuesday, will be the first by a major automaker to bring a zero-emission vehicle to the American market.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  The Nissan Motor Company plans to sell an electric car in the United States and Japan by 2010, raising the stakes in the race to develop environmentally friendly vehicles.

articles.headline: Many Hispanics Are Hit Hard by Economic Slump
articles.snippet: What had been a story of steady advances for Hispanics has given way to growing joblessness and lost homes.
articles.abstract: What had been a story of steady advances for Hispanics has given way to growing joblessness and lost homes.
articles.lead_paragraph: DALTON, Ga.  In his first years in the United States, Carlos B. Jacinto endured the itinerant life of a Guatemalan migrant worker, from picking fruit in Florida to moving logs at a sawmill in Washington. Eventually, he settled here in northern Georgia and erected a middle-class American life.

articles.headline: Powerful Quake Ravages China, Killing Thousands
articles.snippet: An earthquake struck in China, toppling thousands of buildings and killing at least 10,000 people.
articles.abstract: An earthquake struck in China, toppling thousands of buildings and killing at least 10,000 people.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHENGDU, China  A powerful earthquake struck Western China on Monday, toppling thousands of homes, factories and offices, trapping students in schools, and killing at least 10,000 people, the country’s worst natural disaster in three decades.
articles.byline: By Jake Hooker and Jim Yardley

articles.headline: A Wish List for Fixing Wall Street
articles.snippet: For Kenneth C. Griffin, who runs one of the biggest and most successful hedge fund firms, the entire banking industry needs to overhaul its thinking, and perhaps accept greater regulation.
articles.abstract: For Kenneth C. Griffin, who runs one of the biggest and most successful hedge fund firms, the entire banking industry needs to overhaul its thinking, and perhaps accept greater regulation.
articles.lead_paragraph: Kenneth C. Griffin, who runs one of the biggest and most successful hedge fund firms, has a blunt assessment: “We, as an industry, dropped the ball.”
